textRegions.text: Tarek AlmiskiJoe CortesFatimah HoqueMatthias Mohammod
We teach you about coffee. Help you master that favorite drink. And get you caffeinated.

Educational Intent
This application will educate users on how to brew different varieties of coffee. After using the application, users should feel confident in their ability to brew many types of coffee at home.

Target Users
Coffee enthusiasts, cafe frequenters, coffee skeptics. Anyone interested in brewing their own cafe drinks at home will benefit from this application.

This interface will be appropriate both for new coffee drinkers and for those who already know how to make coffee, but would like to learn to brew new varieties at home. For novice users, there will be a step by step tutorial on how to brew coffee.  Advanced users, however, will be able to quickly access information about different varieties of coffee.

very popular drink
great variety is unknown

educate and offer learning tools
make caffeine "more accessible"  (in its many forms)
appeal to coffee skeptics  & current users

Background
21 year college studentHas a high proficiency with computersDoesn’t know much about coffee
GoalsLearn the fundamentals necessary  to brew a cup of coffee.Discover new types of coffee drinks.

Background
65 year old
Has seven grandchildren!Recently began using a computer
Drinks coffee often

GoalsDiscover new and 
unfamiliar types of coffee.

The cost of errors is low, so this is the least emphasized aspect of the interface. However, when errors do occur, we've tried to make the feedback constructive and have the interface blame the system rather than the user.

This goal was not emphasized because we intended the interface to be very quick to learn. However, we have tried to stay close to the user's mental model when possible in order to facilitate this goal. We intended the interface to be as simple as possible, so there would be less for the user to remember.

Although simplicity and speed were our main interface goals, we tried to ensure that the interface was also comfortable for the user. We aimed to use friendly, user-centered language, as well as familiar navigation methods to make the user feel at ease when using the interface.

A primary goal: Ensure that the interface is simple enough that a user will pick it up very quickly. User should spend time learning about coffee, not about the interface. To this end, we tried to provide concise explanations of functionality wherever possible. When appropriate, we used familiar features from other websites in order to leverage the user's past web experience.

Our primary interface goal was to ensure that users can quickly find resources that interest them. Our users will most likely use the site as a reference, so they should not be impeded when they choose to return to the site. We tried to eliminate excise wherever possible, and in particular, limit navigation. The site was also designed to remember user information, saving the user time during subsequent visits.

Github effective for version control and sharing.

Balsamiq easy to create interface mockups

Google+ Hangout easy to have online meetings.

Google Drive great for collaboration

JQuery UI  Widgets difficult to customize and style.

Ambitious prototype  Led to difficulties during development.

Framework
Use an established html framework 
for more consistent structure + styling

Focus
Less features, perfected, than more 
and making them stand out

notes.slide-7:
[Fatimah]

Narrative
Joe is a full time college student and spends a great deal of time studying and work for classes.  Surprisingly, though, he’s not an avid coffee drinker.  He finds himself constantly staying up late and getting up early and would like to introduce coffee into his life to ease the morning drowsiness and keep his all-nighters lively.  Being a college student, he spends a lot of time on the computer and often surfs the web while doing other things.  As coffee is something completely new to Joe, he would use this site periodically when he wishes to learn more about preparing coffee, and exploring other caffeinated choices that may better suit him.  He’d like a place where he can learn all the basics to make a drink quickly so he can get back to his studies.  

Experience Level
Task Semantic
This user has low task semantic knowledge.  He does not drink coffee and thus has no knowledge of the coffee-making process.  
Computer Semantic
This user has high computer semantic knowledge.  He uses the internet regularly and has experience using various websites and software applications.  He also has knowledge of software development, which gives him an intuitive understanding of how applications should work.
App-specific syntax
This user has low app-specific syntax knowledge.  He has not used this particular application before.  He has, however, used many other websites, some of which are of a similar nature.
Characteristics
Work Experience
This user has some work experience that mainly involved doing software development.  As part of the job, he helped to build various programs and he made use of many applications to do his work.
Computer Experience
This user has extensive computer experience.  He has used various software and web applications.  He also has experience in software development.
Education
This user graduated from high school and is working towards a bachelor’s degree in Computer Science.
Reading Skills
This user is a proficient and avid reader.  He has a large vocabulary and high comprehension skills.
Language Skills
This user is fluent in the English language, which is his first language.  He can also read and speak Spanish, but he is not fluent and cannot speak the language at a high level.
notes.slide-14:
[Matthias]
Time to Learn
The application will not be time consuming to learn for new users.  The interface will be straightforward and concise so that users will not have to think too much about how they should use it.  The terminology used will be appropriate to the user, and the definitions of domain-specific terms will be clearly conveyed by the interface.  The intent is that users will spend most of their time with the application learning how to make coffee rather than learning how to use the interface.
notes.slide-26:
JQuery UI - Widgets difficult to customize and style.

Ambitious prototype led to difficulties during development.

Next time: 
Use an established html framework for more consistent structure + styling
Also, focus on less features than more and making them stand out
notes.slide-15:
[Matthias]

Speed of Performance
The application will allow both new and advanced users to quickly find the information that is of interest to them.  To facilitate this goal, the interface will scale based on the user’s knowledge of coffee-making.  New users will be offered an in-depth tutorial on the process of brewing coffee, while advanced users will be offered a streamlined process for finding out about new coffee drinks.  These two levels of the interface will be presented as options to the user that they can choose based on their knowledge of coffee-making.
notes.slide-10:
[Matthias]

following slides, listed in least important to most important

Speed of Performance The application will allow both new and advanced users to quickly find the information that is of interest to them.  To facilitate this goal, the interface will scale based on the user’s knowledge of coffee-making.  New users will be offered an in-depth tutorial on the process of brewing coffee, while advanced users will be offered a streamlined process for finding out about new coffee drinks.  These two levels of the interface will be presented as options to the user that they can choose based on their knowledge of coffee-making.
Time to Learn The application will not be time consuming to learn for new users.  The interface will be straightforward and concise so that users will not have to think too much about how they should use it.  The terminology used will be appropriate to the user, and the definitions of domain-specific terms will be clearly conveyed by the interface.  The intent is that users will spend most of their time with the application learning how to make coffee rather than learning how to use the interface.
Subjective Satisfaction The application will provide users with information regarding the uses, side effects, interactions and warnings
related to drinking coffee. It will also update the user with new recipes. In addition, users will be presented with fun features such as step-by-step guides and games.  Last, but not least, the application will give the user some insight on the history of drinking coffee.  All of these features will be provided in order to make the application enjoyable to use in addition to being informative.

Avoiding User Errors
Since this application will provide options for new and advanced users, both types of users will be less likely to commit errors due to the interface not accommodating their skill level.  In addition, the interface will be simple and concise for all users in order to prevent confusion and decrease the chance of errors.  However, because the consequences of a user error in this application would be minor, this particular criteria will not be emphasized in this interface. 

Retention over time The simplicity of the interface, along with its step-by-step nature, will make it so that the user will not have to learn much in order to use the interface properly.  This will ensure that a repeat user will have an easy time using the interface again, because there will be less things to remember.
notes.slide-16:
tie together with user goals
design choices, justification
cover entire interface well
show explain difference between prototype and the implementation
notes.slide-8:
[Fatimah]

Narrative
Bob is retired, but he's no stranger to coffee. He's been around the caffeine block but his memory isn't a good as out used to be when trying to remember all the trucks of the trade.  Bob has plenty of free time, and does plenty of things with it, including spending a lot of of with the grandchildren. He has ample time to use this application and he is willing to spend a while using it, so long as it is informative and interesting. 
Experience Level
Task Semantic
This user has high task semantic knowledge.  He has been brewing coffee for years, so he is very familiar with the process involved.  He is also familiar with the ingredients necessary for brewing most common types of coffee.
Computer Semantic
This user has low computer semantic knowledge.  He has just started to use a computer on a regular basis, so he has little experience using software applications or navigating the web.  He often finds himself confused on how to use most software applications and usually has to ask someone else for help.
App-specific syntax
This user has low app-specific syntax knowledge.  He has not used this particular application before and he hasn’t used any similar applications.
notes.slide-11:
[Matthias]

Avoiding User Errors
Since this application will provide options for new and advanced users, both types of users will be less likely to commit errors due to the interface not accommodating their skill level.  In addition, the interface will be simple and concise for all users in order to prevent confusion and decrease the chance of errors.  However, because the consequences of a user error in this application would be minor, this particular criteria will not be emphasized in this interface.
notes.slide-12:
[Matthias]

Retention over time
The simplicity of the interface, along with its step-by-step nature, will make it so that the user will not have to learn much in order to use the interface properly.  This will ensure that a repeat user will have an easy time using the interface again, because there will be less things to remember.
notes.slide-5:
[Tarek] 

why we choose this topic

Coffee is one of the most popular, if not THE most popular, drinks in the world [source? my own experience]

Looking around and talking to individuals I have encountered, especially at work, a lot of people don't know about the VARIETY of coffees and caffeinated beverages.  

Talking to some friends and coworkers, many people thought that there was only one type of coffee: the muddy brown liquid that sits in the office coffee pot.  Some people to my surprise hadn't even tried coffee before possibly put off byt the blandness of what theyve seen before.  

A lot of people do drink coffee at cafes, but complain about the price of drinks, or even the difficulty of brewing complex drinks.   - Get Me Caffeinated can help them save money by brewing at home and serves to consolidate knowledge and simplify the process of knowing how to brew.

The application will provide users with information regarding the uses, side effects, interactions and warnings
related to drinking coffee. It will also update the user with new recipes. In addition, users will be presented with fun features such as step-by-step guides and games.  Last, but not least, the application will give the user some insight on the history of drinking coffee.  All of these features will be provided in order to make the application enjoyable to use in addition to being informative.
